prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: No likeable characters (the lead is a combination of the WORST of Woody Allen/Paul Provensa/Reiser) and the contrived scenes (did anyone REALLY think thiat kid on the rollerblades was NOT going to knock the guy down?) were just sickeningly bad.

Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text: This book is definitely an unusual mystery. Though this book may not be anything extraordinary, the main character carries the story on her own and the rest of the characters could easily fade into the background, although the supporting character does a decent job of depicting the authentic atmosphere of the setting. What initially seems like a typical chapter from a popular detective series quickly transforms into a thrilling espionage novel. Nothing particularly remarkable occurs in this straightforward book and ultimately becomes a fairly enjoyable read. Worth checking out, and if you are a fan of strong female protagonists, you might relate to the main character.

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: CCCC is the first good film in Bollywood of 2001. When I first saw the trailer of the film I thought It would be a nice family movie. I was right. Salman Khan has given is strongest performance ever. My family weren't too keen on him but after seeing this film my family are very impressed with him. Rani and Preity are wonderful. The film is going to be a huge hit because of the three main stars.

It's about Raj (Salman Khan) and Priya meeting and falling in love. They get married and go to Switzerland for their honeymoon. When they come back Raj and Priya find out that Priya is pregnant. Raj's family are full of joy when they find out especially Raj's dada (Amrish Puri). Raj and his family are playing cricket one day and Priya has an accident which causes Priya to have a miscarriage. Raj has a very close family friend who is a doctor, Balraj Chopra (Prem Chopra). He tells Raj and Priya that she can no longer have anymore kids. Raj and Priya keep this quiet from the family. Raj and Priya decide to go for surrogacy. Surrogacy to them is that they will find a girl and Raj and that girl will have a baby together and then hand the baby over to Raj and Priya. Raj finds a girl. Her name is Madhubala (Preity Zinta). She is a dancer and a prostitute. Raj tells her the situation and bribes her with money and she agrees. Raj changes Madhubala completley. Raj tells Priya that he has found a girl. Madhubala and Priya meet and become friends. They go to Switzerland to do this so no one finds out. Priya spends the night in a church and Raj and Madhubala are all alone and they spend the night together. The doctor confirms that Madhubala is pregnant and they are all happy. Raj tells his family that Priya is pregnant. They are happy again. Madhubala comes to love Raj and she wants him. What happens next? Watch CCCC to find out.

The one thing I didn't like about the film is their idea of surrogacy. They should have done it the proper way in the film but it didn't ruin the film. It was still excellent.

The songs of the film are great. My favourites are "Chori Chori Chupke Chupke", Dekhne Walon Ne", "Deewana Hai Yeh Mann" and "Mehndi". The song "Mehndi" is very colourful. In that song it shows the ghod bharai taking place and it is very colourful. The film deserves 10/10! Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
I didn't anticipate this situation becoming complicated, Leese. I have to assume she will read it. The tension rises at 30,000 feet in this gripping, action-packed thriller. A red-eye flight to Miami quickly turns into a fight for survival when Lisa (Rachel McAdams) discovers that her seatmate (Cillian Murphy) is plotting a chilling assassination. Racing against time, she must alert the potential targets before it's too late.

One of the reasons why I adore this film is the incredible chemistry between McAdams and Murphy, who happen to be two of my all-time favorite actors. For instance, the initial scenes at the airport have a romantic comedy vibe, with the two characters continually crossing paths. Both McAdams and Murphy deserve praise for their performances in this challenging film. Particularly, Murphy's character, Jackson, is intricately complex. He exudes charm and innocence while simultaneously trapping Lisa physically and mentally. At times, he genuinely appears concerned for her well-being.

This movie is a thrilling roller coaster ride from start to finish. While I typically dislike the idea of prequels or sequels, I wouldn't mind seeing a prequel that focuses on Jackson surveilling Lisa. My favorite scene is undoubtedly the unexpected headbutt moment. The build-up to the famous 'pen' scene is also fantastic. I couldn't help but wonder when Lisa would make her move. Additionally, the transformation of Lisa from a victim to a fighter is impressive. The scene where she sits in the food court and pretends to conduct a survey about the area is brilliant. Murphy's portrayal of Jackson and his wheezing adds another layer of greatness to the film.
